bestBHT.bht: Joseph of Arimathea, in a personal favor, asked for the body of Jesus as a personal favor. The middle voice of his request indicates that he approached Pilate directly, seeking to bury Jesus' body and prevent it from being desecrated by the mob or associated with the two malefactors.

Philip Schaff: Luke 23:52. See Mark 15:43-45, for the particulars of the request to Pilate.
Archibald T. Robertson: Asked for (ηιτησατο). First aorist middle (indirect) indicative as in Mark 15:43; Matthew 27:58. The middle voice shows that Joseph of Arimathea asked the body of Jesus as a personal favour.
John Gill: That he might bury it, [...] and prevent its being inferred with the two malefactors, or abused by the mob.

bhtAttempts.bht: Joseph of Arimathea, in an act of personal favor, asked Pilate for the body of Jesus. This bold request, made in the knowledge that Jesus was dead, allowed Joseph to bury it and prevent any further desecration or abuse by the mob or association with the two malefactors. (Based on Luke 23:52 and related passages)

In a demonstration of personal favor, Joseph of Arimathea went boldly to Pilate and asked for Jesus' body, knowing that He was dead. His intention was to bury the body and prevent any further desecration or abuse in association with the two malefactors or by the mob.

In a personal favor, Joseph of Arimathea asked for the body of Jesus as he went boldly to Pilate. Aware that Jesus was dead, Joseph sought to bury the body to prevent it from being inferred with the two malefactors or from being abused by the mob.

Joseph of Arimathea, in a personal favor, asked for the body of Jesus as a personal favor. The middle voice of his request indicates that he approached Pilate directly, seeking to bury Jesus' body and prevent it from being desecrated by the mob or associated with the two malefactors.

Joseph of Arimathea, seeking a personal favor, asked for the body of Jesus as a personal favor. He went boldly to Pilate, knowing that Jesus was dead. His intention was to bury the body and prevent it from being inferred with the two malefactors or abused by the mob.
